docs.snippet: BISHOP'S STORTFORD, England, Feb. 28 - A 48-hour hijacking drama that began in East Africa ended tonight at an airport 25 miles northeast of London with the surrender of four young terrorists and the release of more than 90 hostages.   The Air Tan...
docs.lead_paragraph: BISHOP'S STORTFORD, England, Feb. 28 - A 48-hour hijacking drama that began in East Africa ended tonight at an airport 25 miles northeast of London with the surrender of four young terrorists and the release of more than 90 hostages. The Air Tanzania airliner was hijacked on Friday while it was on a domestic flight. The terrorists forced the pilot to fly to Nairobi, Kenya, then to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, Athens and finally to Stansted Airport, which is used principally for charter flights.

byline.original: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The quiet residential community of Bayside, Queens, long a center of one-family homes, is experiencing a surge in new housing construction. During the next year more than 2,000 new units will be offered for sale, mainly in condominium projects now...
docs.lead_paragraph: The quiet residential community of Bayside, Queens, long a center of one-family homes, is experiencing a surge in new housing construction. During the next year more than 2,000 new units will be offered for sale, mainly in condominium projects now in various stages of development. While community residents debate whether Bayside can accommodate the new growth, many area builders have been attracted to the parcels of land in Bayside and elsewhere along the lengthy shorefront of northern Queens. As in other parts of the metropolitan area, water is a lure to development.

headline.main: WATERFRONT IS A MAGNET IN QUEENS

docs.snippet: Back in 1969, when George H. Buck Jr. bought the catalogue of World Transcriptions, one of the major radio transcription services of the 1930's and 40's, a Swing Era fan could envision a flood of recordings by most of the big bands of the period t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Back in 1969, when George H. Buck Jr. bought the catalogue of World Transcriptions, one of the major radio transcription services of the 1930's and 40's, a Swing Era fan could envision a flood of recordings by most of the big bands of the period that had never before been available to the public. Radio transcriptions were made only for use by radio stations and were not for public sale. But 20 years after there was any reason to have radio transcriptions, that limitation could be overlooked. Unfortunately, Mr. Buck, a radio executive who got into the recording business in 1949, when he started Jazzology Records to make an album by the jazz clarinetist Tony Parenti, and has since enlarged both Jazzology and another label, GBH, while acquiring a number of small jazz labels, was not able to start releasing his World Transcription acquisitions for almost a decade. But in the past two or three years they have begun to trickle out, and albums of World Transcription recordings by Red Norvo's band, Bob Crosby's band, Harry James, Russ Morgan and John Kirby have been released.

headline.main: BIG BANDS SWING AGAIN ON NEW DISKS

docs.snippet: After a 33-month investigation, the Justice Department is preparing to seek indictments against several persons in connection with the slaying of a Federal district judge in San Antonio, Tex., according to department officials.   The officials, wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: After a 33-month investigation, the Justice Department is preparing to seek indictments against several persons in connection with the slaying of a Federal district judge in San Antonio, Tex., according to department officials. The officials, who asked that they not be identified, said that prosecutors planned to ask a Federal grand jury in San Antonio to return the indictments within 30 days. Judge John H. Wood Jr. was killed by a rifle bullet as he left his San Antonio town house the morning of May 29, 1979. He was the first Federal judge slain in more than a century.

headline.main: U.S. PREPARING INDICTMENTS IN MURDER OF JUDGE IN 1979

byline.original: By EDWARD T. POUND, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A hijacked Air Tanzania jet carrying about 90 people arrived from Athens today and was immediately surrounded by the police at Stansted Airport north of London.   The four hijackers threatened to blow up the plane if security forces moved in.  Rob...
docs.lead_paragraph: A hijacked Air Tanzania jet carrying about 90 people arrived from Athens today and was immediately surrounded by the police at Stansted Airport north of London. The four hijackers threatened to blow up the plane if security forces moved in. Robert Bunyard, the Essex Chief Constable, said a demand from the hijackers to refuel the plane had been refused. ''It is not my intention to allow this airplane to leave this airport,'' he said.

docs.snippet: Roberto D'Aubuisson, the principal rightist candidate in El Salvador's elections, was slightly wounded by a gunshot in the back this afternoon as he was leaving the capital for a campaign appearance in a provincial city.   The attack followed by l...
docs.lead_paragraph: Roberto D'Aubuisson, the principal rightist candidate in El Salvador's elections, was slightly wounded by a gunshot in the back this afternoon as he was leaving the capital for a campaign appearance in a provincial city. The attack followed by less than 24 hours a machine-gun and grenade assault on the headquarters of his Nationalist Republican Alliance party in which another candidate and three associates were wounded. The assailants in both incidents sped away unidentified. The threat of violence has been the principal preoccupation of those organizing and supporting the March 28 elections, which are central to United States policy in El Salvador.

headline.main: RIGHTEST LEADER IN SALVADOR IS WOUNDED IN ATTACK

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: ANTHONY ZERBE will star in ''Solomon's Child,'' which will open at the Little Theater on April 8. Mr. Zerbe, who most recently played Elizabeth Taylor's brother Ben in ''The Little Foxes,'' will play a deprogrammer named Balthazar. He deprograms y...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANTHONY ZERBE will star in ''Solomon's Child,'' which will open at the Little Theater on April 8. Mr. Zerbe, who most recently played Elizabeth Taylor's brother Ben in ''The Little Foxes,'' will play a deprogrammer named Balthazar. He deprograms young people who have been abducted from cults. Everyone connected with ''Solomon's Child,'' however, solemnly agrees that it is not so much about deprogramming as it is about parents, children and a society in which cults flourish. Therefore, they are calling it ''a contemporary mystery.'' Whatever they call it, the play by Tom Dulack was nicely received when it was done at the Long Wharf Theater last season. ''Solomon's Child,'' which will be directed by John Tillinger, will also feature Joanna Merlin, Deborah Hedwall and Keith Gordon. Some of their separate distinctions, athough not necessarily the most important ones, are that Mr. Tillinger directed the recent, highly praised ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane'' off Broadway; Miss Merlin is Harold Prince's casting director; Miss Hedwall was particularly well received when she created her role at Long Wharf, and Mr. Gordon was Angie Dickinson's son in the movie ''Dressed to Kill.'' The play will be produced by F.D.M. Productions, which is also co-producing the musical ''Is There Life After High School?'' F.D.M. is run by Francois de Menil and Harris Maslansky.

headline.main: Broadway; 'Solomon's Child,' Play About Cults, Opens April 8

docs.snippet: Works by the composer John Cage can be seen but not heard in a survey of his visual achievements at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Cage developed his own systems of musical notation in the 1930's, and the exhibition, celebrating his 70th birt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Works by the composer John Cage can be seen but not heard in a survey of his visual achievements at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Cage developed his own systems of musical notation in the 1930's, and the exhibition, celebrating his 70th birthday, offers selections of his hand-drawn music scores, including one that uses stars rather than musical notes as points of reference and another consisting of two lithographs and eight silk-screened plexiglass sheets arranged at random on a wooden base. Also on view is nonmusical graphic work by Cage and a 216-image photographic portrait of the composer by Robert Mahon. Concerts of Cage music are planned March 31-April 2 (admission: $5 for each). Admission to the museum, at Madison and 75th Street, is $2 (free for children, students and the elderly).

headline.main: Weekender Guide; Friday; CAGE AT THE WHITNEY

docs.snippet: NO matter who wins the Academy Award for best actress of 1981, it won't be Glenda Jackson for ''Stevie.'' Miss Jackson, who came to New York last month to accept the New York Film Critics Circle award (two weeks earlier, she got an award from the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: NO matter who wins the Academy Award for best actress of 1981, it won't be Glenda Jackson for ''Stevie.'' Miss Jackson, who came to New York last month to accept the New York Film Critics Circle award (two weeks earlier, she got an award from the National Board of Review) for playing the poet Stevie Smith, is not eligible for an Oscar. Why? Because ''Stevie'' opened in Los Angeles two years ago. Then how could the New York critics give Miss Jackson their award? Because ''Stevie'' didn't open in New York two years ago; it opened in New York only last year. For two days. At the Thalia Theater on a double-bill with something called ''Forbush and the Penguin.'' And Vincent Canby saw it and wrote an enthusiastic review in The New York Times. The result was ''Stevie'' mania, a phenomenon that baffles Miss Jackson. ''You explain it to me,'' she says. ''After we made the picture, it went to the Montreal Film Festival, where it got awards. And it played in L.A., where it got very nice notices. And it played in England, where it got very nice notices. And nobody showed it in New York, and it disappeared off the face of the earth.

headline.main: At the Movies; No Oscar this year for Miss Jackson.

docs.snippet: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences refused today to accede to the Polish Government's request that ''Man of Iron'' be withdrawn as Poland's entry for an Academy Award. ''Man of Iron,'' a movie directed by Andrzej Wajda that extols the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences refused today to accede to the Polish Government's request that ''Man of Iron'' be withdrawn as Poland's entry for an Academy Award. ''Man of Iron,'' a movie directed by Andrzej Wajda that extols the Solidarity union movement, is one of the five finalists in the foreign-language category. J. Zaporowski, director of Film Polski, an official Polish agency, sent a cable to the academy Tuesday asking that ''Man of Iron'' be withdrawn because of the ''anti-Polish attitudes of the United States.''

headline.main: 'MAN OF IRON' WILL STAY IN OSCAR RACE

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times
